H0.text: Abbreviations for each element are shown in a chemical equation, whereas a chemical formula does not display them.

H1.text: The number of atoms per element is shown in a chemical equation, distinguishing it from a chemical formula.

H2.text: What elements are in each molecule is shown by a chemical equation, distinguishing it from a chemical formula.

H3.text: The chemical reaction that takes place is shown by a chemical equation, distinguishing it from a chemical formula.

A4.text: A chemical equation represents the transformation of reactants into products, illustrating the chemical reaction that occurs, which is distinct from a chemical formula that merely denotes the composition of a substance.

A5.text: Chemical equations use coefficients to indicate the number of molecules or atoms involved in a reaction, thereby specifying the quantitative relationship between reactants and products, a feature not inherent to chemical formulas alone.

A6.text: The chemical formulas may be symbolic, structural (pictorial diagrams), or intermixed.

A7.text: Because no nuclear reactions take place in a chemical reaction, the chemical elements pass through the reaction unchanged. Thus, each side of the chemical equation must represent the same number of atoms of any particular element...
